facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1225 and 1226 of 1967 are appeals from the judgment and decree dated May 22, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 189 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1225 and 1226 of 1967. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated May 22, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 189 of 1953.

facts.text: Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai is a registered firm carrying on business in piece goods and commission agents with head office at Kanpur and branch at Farrukhabad.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai-hereinafter called the assessee-is a registered firm carrying on a business in piece goods and companymission agents. It has its head office at Kanpur and a branch office at Farrukhabad.

facts.text: During chargeable accounting periods July 4, 1943 to June 21, 1944 and June 22, 1944 to July 10, 1945, Gurbux Rai and Harbux Rai each representing his joint family were partners with equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: During the chargeable accounting periods July 4, 1943 to June 21, 1944 and June 22, 1944 to July 10, 1945 Gurbux Rai and Harbux Rai  each representing his joint family  were the two partners of the assessees with equal shares in the profit and loss.

facts.text: Assessee informed Tax Officer that joint family of Gurbux Rai was dissolved and partnership reconstituted from July 4, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment of tax under the Excess Profits for Act 1940 for the two chargeable accounting periods the assessee informed the Tax Officer that the joint family of Gurbux Rai had been dissolved and there was a reconstitution of the business of the partnership with effect from July 4, 1943.

facts.text: After partition, Kanpur firm had two partners with equal shares; Farrukhabad had Harbux Rai 8 annas, Chameli Devi 4 annas, Gopaldas 4 annas.

anchor.surface_text: , According to the assessee the companystitution of the firm after partition was that in the firm at Kanpur the former two partners were interested, their share being equal, but in the business of the firm at Farrukhabad there were three partners-Harbux Rai with -/8/- share, Chameli Devi with -/4/- share and Gopaldas with -/4/- share.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer for AY 1944-45 held partition claim not acceptable and assessed as single assessee firm including Farrukhabad.

anchor.surface_text: In assessing tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 for the assessment year 1944-45 relevant to the account year ending June 21, 1944 the Income-tax Officer held that the case set up by the assessee that there was partition amongst the members of the family of Gurbux Rai companyld number be accepted.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer assessed entire income of Kanpur and Farrukhabad in hands of assessee firm consequential to income-tax assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The excess profits tax assessment being companysequential upon the income-tax assessment, the Excess Profits Tax Officer assessed the entire income of the two businesses at Kanpur and at Farrukhabad, in the hands of the assessee firm.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner by order dated October 10, 1947 held partial partition of Gurbux Rai family movable property near Asadh Samvat 2000, Farrukhabad run by separate firm Harbux Rai, Chameli Devi, Gopaldas.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Income Tax Officer the assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who by his order dated October 10, 1947 observed that partial partition in respect of movable property of Gurbux Rai was effected on a date somewhere near Asadh Samvat 2000, from which date Farrukhabad was companyducted by a separate firm companysisting of Harbux Rai, Mst. Chameli and Gopaldas.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer modified assessments for 1944-45 and 1945-46 pursuant to AAC order.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order the Income-tax Officer modified the assessment with respect to the Income-tax assessment of the assessee for the assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer issued notice dated February 6, 1951 under s.10A calling for cause why adjustments not made.

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer however started proceedings under s. 10-A by numberice dated February 6, 1951 calling upon the assessee to show cause why appropriate adjustments should number be made in the assessment,

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer by order dated February 21, 1951 under s.15 modified assessments including Farrukhabad income, holding main purpose avoidance of EPT.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated February 21, 1951 passed under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act the Excess Profits Tax Officer modified the original excess profits tax assessment. In the revised assessment in pursuance of orders under s. 10-A he included the income of the branch shop at Farrukhabad

facts.text: Assessee contended EPT Officer not competent under s.15 as no definite information, and not under s.10A in revised assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed against the order of additional assessment companytending that the Excess Profits Tax Officer was number companypetent to reopen the case under s. 15 as he had numberdefinite information companying into his possession to enable him to discover that the profits of the chargeable accounting period had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held EPT Officer had definite information from AAC order and competent under s.10A.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the Excess Profits Tax Officer had received definite information regarding the state of the law in pursuance of the appellate order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who had held that the family of Gurbux Rai was partially partitioned.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to Allahabad High Court under s.21 EPT Act r/w s.66(1) IT Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thereafter referred the following questions to the High Court of Allahabad under s. 21 of the Excess Profits Act read with s. 66  1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case there was any definite information within the meaning of s. 15

facts.text: Allahabad High Court answered both questions in negative on May 22, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad held that since the Excess Profits Tax Officer purported to reopen the assessment under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act only because of the order of-the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income- tax holding that the Farrukhabad business

facts.text: There was a parallel proceeding Civil Appeals Nos. 741-743 of 1966 decided August 2, 1968 where HC on July 31, 1969 held transaction avoidable under s.10A, final.

anchor.surface_text: A parallel proceeding which had companye before this Court in Civil Appeals Nos. 741-743 of 1966 Gurbux Rai Harbux Rai v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. decided on August 2, 1968 may also be referred to.

facts.text: Supreme Court by order January 21, 1971 directed Tribunal for supplementary statement on whether s.10A in course of s.15 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals this Court by an order dated January 21, 1971 directed the Income tax Appellate Tribunal to submit a supplementary statement of the case on the question whether the proceedings under s. 10-A were started

facts.text: Supplementary statement confirms notices under s.15 and s.10A issued February 3, 1951, s.15 first, proceedings pending.

anchor.surface_text: It has stated that the numberices under s. 15 of the Act were issued for both the chargeable accounting periods and they were served on the assessee on February 3, 1951. According to these numberices the assessee was called upon to show cause why provisions of s. 10A

facts.text: EPT Officer passed order under s.10A on February 21, 1951 after approval.

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer obtained approval of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and passed an order under s. 10A on February 21, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court held proceedings under s.15 valid due to definite information from AAC order dated October 10, 1947, and s.10A applicable therein.

anchor.surface_text: The first. question, therefore, should have been answered against the assessee and in favour of the Revenue. The appeals succeed and are allowed with companyts. The answers, to both the questions are returned in favour of the Revenue.

facts.text: Partial partition of Gurbux Rai family movable property effected near Asadh Samvat 2000.

anchor.surface_text: partial partition in respect of movable property of Gurbux Rai was effected on a date somewhere near Asadh Samwat at 2000, from which date Farrukhabad business was companyducted by a separate firm

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case there was any definite information within the meaning of s. 15 by virtue of which the Excess Profits Tax Officer was competent to reopen the excess profits tax assessments?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case there was any definite information within the meaning of s. 15 by virtue of which the Excess Profits Tax Officer was competent to reopen the excess profits tax assessments ?

issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of this case, the Excess Profits Tax Officer was competent to apply the provisions of s. 10-A and make necessary adjustments, in pursuance thereto in the revised assessment under s. 15

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of this case, the Excess Profits Tax Officer was competent to apply the provisions of s. 10-A and make necessary adjustments,in pursuance thereto in the revised assessment under s. 15

issues.text: Whether the proceedings under s. 10-A were started in the course of assessment or reassessment proceedings commenced under s. 15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act 1940

issues.text: Whether the Excess Profits Tax Officer had definite information from the appellate order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in income-tax proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner had made an order on October 10, 1947 in the proceedings relating to the assessment of income tax of the assessee that there had been only a partial partition

arguments.claim: Excess Profits Tax Officer was not competent to reopen the case under s. 15 as he had no definite information coming into his possession to enable him to discover that the profits had escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed against the order of additional assessment contending that the Excess Profits Tax Officer was not competent to reopen the case under s. 15 as he had no definite information coming into his possession to enable him to discover that the profits of the chargeable accounting period had escaped assessment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellate Assistant Commissioner's order on partial partition is definite information from superior authority, even if material previously available; in pari materia with IT Act s.34(1)(b)

arguments.claim: All materials were before the Excess Profits Tax Officer at original assessment and no new information came thereafter

anchor.surface_text: The assessee contended that all the materials in the case were before the Excess Profits Tax Officer at the time of his original assessment and no new information came into his possession thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was right in so holding. S. 10-A does not contemplate an independent proceeding. Section 10- A merely confers power upon the Excess Profits Tax Officer to make adjustments with respect to liability to excess profits tax it confers power which the Excess Profits Tax Officer may exercise in the course of the ,original assessment or in the course of re-assessment.

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s.15 commenced before s.10A as notices issued same day but s.15 first per order-sheet

holdings.text: S. 10-A does not contemplate an independent proceeding. Section 10-A merely confers power upon the Excess Profits Tax Officer to make adjustments with respect to liability to excess profits tax; it confers power which the Excess Profits Tax Officer may exercise in the course of the original assessment or in the course of re-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was right in so holding. S. 10-A does not contemplate an independent proceeding. Section 10- A merely confers power upon the Excess Profits Tax Officer to make adjustments with respect to liability to excess profits tax it confers power which the Excess Profits Tax Officer may exercise in the course of the ,original assessment or in the course of re-assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.10A; power incidental to pending assessment/reassessment; High Court correctly held this.

holdings.text: The proceedings under s.15 were pending when proceedings under s.10A were initiated, as notices under s.15 were issued first on the same day per order-sheet.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding from supplementary statement and order-sheet; s.15 notice first despite same date; not hypertechnical.

holdings.text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer had definite information under s.15 from the Appellate Assistant Commissioner's order dated October 10, 1947 holding partial partition, constituting information from superior authority.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner had made an order on October 10, 1947 in the proceedings relating to the assessment of income tax of the assessee that there had been only a partial partition in respect of the movable property  business  of Gurbux Rai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC order in income-tax proceedings is definite information triggering discovery of escaped profits; not mere change of opinion.

holdings.text: s.15 of EPT Act is in pari materia with s.34(1)(b) of IT Act 1922; information from decision of superior authorities or court suffices for jurisdiction under s.15 even if in assessment proceedings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent Supreme Court precedents (Bansilal, Estate Duty cases) apply due to pari materia provisions.

holdings.text: The first question (definite information under s.15) should have been answered in favour of Revenue; the second question (competence for s.10A in s.15 reassessment) also in favour of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The first. question, therefore, should have been answered against the assessee and in favour of the Revenue. The appeals succeed and are allowed with costs. The answers, to both the questions are returned in favour of the Revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct answers to referred questions based on above holdings; appeals allowed.

holdings.text: Once s.15 proceedings initiated based on definite information of partial partition, EPT Officer competent under s.10A to examine if purpose was avoidance of EPT liability.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10A of the Act is a special provision which deals with the transactions designed to avoid or reduce liability to excess profits tax. The information which came into possession of the Excess Profits Tax. Officer of partial partition having been effected was relevant for the purpose of s. 15

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10A examination distinct from income-tax proceedings; triggered post s.15 initiation.
